contentrichtext.text: [[File:GeorgeRawlinson.jpg|thumbnail|250px|right|George Rawlinson, M.A., F.R.G.S., Canon of Canterbury and Camden Professor of Ancient History at the University of Oxford]] Canon '''George Rawlinson''' (23 November 1812 – 7 October 1902) was a 19th-century [[England|English]] [[scholar]], [[historian]], and [[Christian theology|Christian theologian]]. He was born at [[Chadlington]], [[Oxfordshire]],<ref>{{cite journal |title='''RAWLINSON, Rev. Canon George'''|journal= Who's Who|volume=53|year=1901|pages= p. 931|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=8EcuAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA931}}</ref> and was the younger brother of [[Sir Henry Rawlinson, 1st Baronet|Sir Henry Rawlinson]]. Having taken his degree at the [[University of Oxford]] (from [[Trinity College, Oxford|Trinity College]]) in 1838, he was elected to a fellowship at [[Exeter College, Oxford]], in 1840, of which from 1842 to 1846 he was fellow and tutor. He was ordained in 1841, was [[Bampton lecturer]] in 1859, and was [[Camden Professor of Ancient History]] from 1861 to 1889. In his early days at Oxford, he played [[cricket]] for the [[Oxford University Cricket Club|University]], appearing in five matches between 1836 and 1839 which have since been considered to have been [[first-class cricket|first-class]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/37/37561/37561.html| title = George Rawlinson | publisher = www.cricketarchive.com | accessdate = 12 April 2013}}</ref> In 1872 he was appointed [[canon (priest)|canon]] of [[Canterbury]], and after 1888 he was rector of All Hallows, [[Lombard Street, London|Lombard Street]]. In 1873, he was appointed proctor in Convocation for the Chapter of Canterbury. He married Louisa, daughter of Sir RA Chermside, in 1846. His chief publications are his [[translation]] of the ''[[The Histories of Herodotus|History]]'' of [[Herodotus]] (in collaboration with Sir Henry Rawlinson and Sir [[John Gardiner Wilkinson]]), 1858–60; ''The Five Great Monarchies of the Ancient Eastern World'', 1862–67; ''The Sixth Great Oriental Monarchy'' ([[Parthia]]n), 1873; ''The Seventh Great Oriental Monarchy'' ([[Sassanid dynasty|Sassanian]]), 1875; ''Manual of Ancient History'', 1869; ''Historical Illustrations of the Old Testament'', 1871; ''The Origin of Nations'', 1877; ''History of Ancient Egypt'', 1881; ''Egypt and Babylon'', 1885; ''History of Phoenicia'', 1889; ''Parthia'', 1893; ''Memoir of Major-General Sir HC Rawlinson'', 1898. His lectures to an audience at [[Oxford University]] on the topic of the accuracy of the Bible in 1859 were published as the [[Christian apologetics|apologetic]] work ''The Historical Evidences of the Truth of the Scripture Records Stated Anew'' in later years. He was also contributor to the Speaker's Commentary, the Pulpit Commentary, Smith's ''Dictionary of the Bible'', and various similar publications.
